properties.title: Sep  2, 2010: Abbey Road On The River - Washington DC at Gayload National: Washington D.C.
properties.description:
Abbey Road on the River (AROTR) is a music festival honoring the music and legend of The Beatles. It takes place in Louisville, Kentucky on Memorial Day weekend and in Washington DC Labor Day weekend at National Harbor, MD, both lasting five days. Attracting over 30,000 attendants to Louisville's Belvedere, Abbey Road on the River is the largest Beatles festival in the United States.
Abbey Road on the River hosts many different types of Tribute Bands. Some bands look, sound, and behave like the Beatles. Other bands play Beatles music accurately, but do not dress or act as Beatles. Other bands celebrate the music of Lennon & McCartney and George Harrison without trying to reproduce the Beatles' sound.

properties.title: Jul  9, 2010: The Art of Gaman: Arts and Crafts From the Japanese American Internment Camps, 1942-1946 at Renwick Gallery
properties.description: This exhibit will showcase arts and crafts made by Japanese Americans in U.S. internment camps during World War II. On display will be more than 100 objects, many of which are on loan from former internees or their families. The exhibition is based on Delphine Hirasuna's 2005 book 'The Art of Gaman.'

properties.title: Jul  9, 2010: Since Darwin: the Evolution of Evolution at National Museum of Natural History
properties.description: Join others in celebrating the 200th anniversary of Charles Darwin's birth and the 150th anniversary of the publication of his groundbreaking 'On the Origin of Species.' Specimens from the Museum's diverse collections, along with documentation from ongoing research, illustrate the importance of evolution as a scientific foundation, and how our knowledge of evolution has evolved over the last 150 years.

properties.title: Jul  9, 2010: Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Happiness at American Visionary Art Museum
properties.description: The quest for human rights and the search for personal fulfillment, as proposed in the 1776 American Declaration of Independence, provide the starting point for this upcoming international exhibition. Works by the last surviving descendant of the Tsars of Russia, Iroquois Indians, French Revolutionaries, illegal immigrants, Algerian War veterans, Guantanamo Bay detainees, Holocaust survivors, incarcerated prisoners, African-American civil rights activists and Iraqi doctors are among the 50 visionary artists to be featured.

properties.title: Jul  9, 2010: Inside Tim Russert's Office: If It's Sunday, It's 'Meet the Press' at Newseum
properties.description: One of the country's most respected journalists, Tim Russert moderated 'Meet the Press' for nearly 17 years. This exhibit recreates Russert's NBC Washington office much as it looked when he died of a heart attack in June 2008 while preparing for his next show. Family, faith and sports were important themes in Russert's life, as evidenced by his favorite books, family photos and mementos of his beloved Buffalo Bills that line his office. A Newseum-produced video features some of Russert's more memorable interviews and remembrances from those who worked with him and knew him best.

properties.title: Jul 28, 2010: Abraham Lincoln Certified Plate Proofs at National Postal Museum
properties.description: On view in the Philatelic Gallery pullout frames at the Museum are 11 certified plate proofs for postage stamps honoring Abraham Lincoln. Certified plate proofs are the last printed proof of the plate before printing the stamps. These plate proofs are each unique, with the approval signatures and date. Issued from 1894 to 1959, the stamps feature a variety of Lincoln portraits.

properties.title: Jul 28, 2010: Intersections Art Projects - Tayo Heuser: Pulse at The Phillips Collection
properties.description: Tayo Heuser translates the luminosity of Mark Rothko's paintings into three dimensions with large-scale wall-mounted sculptures of glowing, colored forms drawn in ink, designed to rise along the spiral flow of the Goh Annex stairwell. The work was created in response to both the architecture of the stairwell and the paintings in the museum's Rothko Room. This exhibit is part of Intersections Art Projects, in which artists respond to art and spaces in the Phillips with projects of their own.

properties.title: Jul  9, 2010: Capital Harvest on the Plaza Farm Market at Woodrow Wilson Plaza
properties.description:
Located on the Woodrow Wilson Plaza, The Capital Harvest on the Plaza Farm Market's mission is to bring quality, locally grown fresh produce and related products from the farms to the consumers’ table as well as providing the tools necessary to implement a healthy lifestyle. This Farm Market gives the farmers, producers, crafters and artisans from around the Chesapeake region the opportunity to provide a wide variety of quality fresh produce and related products directly to the consumer at affordable prices. 
The Farm Market will also be showcasing local chefs who will demonstrate dishes inspired by the produce available at the Farm Market, along with tasting samples and recipe, on a weekly basis. Live musical entertainment will accommodate this communal experience!
The Capital Harvest on the Plaza Farmers Market is supported by the GSA.

properties.description: The Farmers’ Market at the historic train station is a Saturday tradition in Kensington. The market offers seasonal produce, seafood, meat, plants and flowers from small regional farmers. Other specialties include artisan breads, jams, olive oil, chocolates and much more.

properties.title: Jul 10, 2010: Roof Terrace Restaurant hosts a Magical Afternoon Tea Party at Roof Terrace Restaurant
properties.description:
Mary Poppins is floating into The Kennedy Center this summer and in honor of the charmed caretaker, the KC Café is hosting a Magical Afternoon Tea Party after every matinee performance. Starting on Saturday, July 3rd, the KC Café will welcome youngsters for a late afternoon tea with cupcake decorating, mini-sandwiches, cookies, and a visit by a chim chim-in-ey chimney sweep. The tea party will take place from 4:15 p.m. – 5:15 p.m. and is priced at $25 for children and $29 for adults. 
During the tea, Pastry Chef Ben McCormick will visit with the kids to discuss cupcake making and decorating tips before they dive in and create their own edible masterpieces.  The menu is stacked with kid friendly treats like mini- Nutella and banana, butter and strawberry jam, and ham and cheese sandwiches, as well as cookies, and fruit tarts all served with lemonade, ice tea and fruit punch. 
Parents shall fear not, there will be something for everyone. As the kiddies decorate cupcakes, adults can relax and enjoy the unmatched view of the Washington, DC skyline while delighting in a tea of their own with mini- pimento cheese and smoked salmon with dill crème fraiche sandwiches, European macaroons, scones and a variety of hot teas like earl gray, green tea and lady gray. There will also be wine and cava available for purchase.  
The Magical Afternoon Tea Party will be held after every matinee from July 1st through August 22nd. Space is limited and reservations are required. To make reservations please contact Jeff Wingate at 202-416-8559. 
In addition, Executive Chef Joe Gurner at the Roof Terrace Restaurant at the Kennedy Center is taking cues from Ms. Poppins and will present family friendly menus. Please check the website at www.roofterracerestaurant.com for more information.

properties.title: Jul  9, 2010: Grand Salon Installation - Paintings From the Smithsonian American Art Museum at Renwick Gallery
properties.description: This installation features 70 paintings from the Smithsonian American Art Museum's collection. On display will be landscapes, portraits, and allegorical works by 51 American artists from the 1840s to the 1930s. The room is installed salon style, with paintings hung one-atop-another and side by side. A visitor guide will be available in the Grand Salon with short biographies of the artists.

properties.title: Jul  9, 2010: Postal Inspectors: the Silent Service at National Museum of American
properties.description: Today about 2,000 postal inspectors are at work across the United States investigating crimes against the mail. By visiting the museum and viewing this exhibit, you'll learn more about the inspectors and what their jobs entail. Sometimes called the silent service, the U.S. Postal Inspection Service is one of the oldest federal law enforcement agencies in the country.

properties.title: Jul  9, 2010: Supporting the Force: Navy Supply in Action - Ready for Sea, Ready Ashore at US Navy Memorial
properties.description: Navy Supply provides the "beans, bullets and black oil" that enable the US Navy to operate around the globe. Navy Supply touches the lives of every sailor with food, laundry, barbers, postal services and ship's stores. On display will be ship models, rare historic artifacts including an 1841 Navy Purser's uniform coat - the oldest known Navy Supply uniform - as well as a World War II WAVE uniform and the uniform and equipment worn by a Navy Advisor in the Vietnam War. In addition, the exhibit will honor the sailors of Navy Supply who've given their lives in the Global War on Terror and those who've received the Nation's top honors. Hands on activities for children include "build a meal" puzzles, interactive cargo handling display model and a "try-on trunk" with flight deck uniforms and equipment used during vertical replenishment operations. A full schedule of events will accompany the exhibit, including food tastings, films, lectures and equipment displays.

properties.title: Jul  9, 2010: Victory Mail at National Museum of American
properties.description: This exhibit showcases the Museum's collection of World War II V-Mail correspondence. V for Victory, a popular symbol of the Second World War, was the inspiration for the name of this new fangled correspondence style.

properties.title: Jul  9, 2010: Perspectives: Hai Bo at Arthur M Sackler Gallery
properties.description: Trained as a painter, Hai Bo, born in 1962 in Changchun, China, took up photography in the 1980s as he became captivated by the camera's ability to stop time and evoke memories. For over two decades, he has been returning to his hometown in Jilin Province to capture the people and places of his youth, creating deeply moving portraits of resilience amidst the growing isolation of rural China. On display are five stunning, large scale photographs from his Northern Series. These images allow viewers to enter the vast panoramas of the artist's childhood memories, observe the subtle changes of nature across seasons, and encounter the gentle transience of life.

properties.title: Jul  9, 2010: Athlete: the Sports Illustrated Photography of Walter Iooss at Newseum
properties.description: On display are more than 40 photos from Iooss's nearly 50-year career, each accompanied by the story behind the image, told in Iooss's own words. The exhibit includes Iooss's most famous photograph, 'The Catch,' which captured the last-minute touchdown catch by San Francisco 49ers' receiver Dwight Clark that ended the Dallas Cowboys' Super Bowl dreams in 1982. Also included are Iooss's personal diaries, filled with collages of his photos, quirky headlines and his handwritten notes. In addition, the exhibit includes an original Newseum-produced video in which Iooss talks about his photos and the bond he forged with his subjects.

properties.title: Jul  9, 2010: First Dogs: Presidential Pets in the White House at Newseum
properties.description: One of the Newseum's most popular exhibits showcases some of the top dogs who have resided at the nation's most prestigious address. On display are images of dogs belonging to 23 presidents, including the newest addition: Bo, a six-month-old Portuguese water dog.

properties.title: Jul  9, 2010: Elvis - His Groundbreaking, Hip-Shaking, Newsmaking Story at Newseum
properties.description: Experience the power of Elvis Presley and the explosive impact he had on music and popular culture. The exhibit opens in what would have been Presley's 75th birthday year. It tells the story of Presley as he was portrayed in the news media and explores how his music and physicality pushed the boundaries of mainstream taste and free expression. Produced in collaboration with Elvis Presley Enterprises Inc., the exhibit includes a number of rare objects from the vaults of Graceland that have never been publicly displayed, including private telegrams, letters and documents that chronicle Presley's rise as a music and media sensation. Also on display are rare photographs and original newspapers and magazines covering Presley's career, Presley's iconic 1957 Harley-Davidson motorcycle, the "American Eagle" jumpsuit and cape Presley wore during rehearsals for his 1973 "Aloha From Hawaii" concert and the gold-and-diamond belt presented to Presley in 1969 for breaking Las Vegas attendance records.

properties.title: Jul 11, 2010: Contemporary Craft and Decorative Arts at Renwick Gallery
properties.description: The museum's Renwick Gallery is home to the nation's premier collection of American studio craft and contemporary decorative arts. The permanent collection features works in all of the craft media - glass, ceramic, wood, fiber and metal - as well as mixed media objects. Jewelry and studio furniture make up a significant part of the collection.

properties.title: Jul 12, 2010: Contemporary Craft and Decorative Arts at Renwick Gallery
properties.description: The museum's Renwick Gallery is home to the nation's premier collection of American studio craft and contemporary decorative arts. The permanent collection features works in all of the craft media - glass, ceramic, wood, fiber and metal - as well as mixed media objects. Jewelry and studio furniture make up a significant part of the collection.

properties.title: Jul 11, 2010: Bird Watching at Great Falls Park
properties.description: Meet in the Visitor Center Courtyard.

properties.title: Jul 11, 2010: Global Warming Facts and Our Future at Marian Koshland Science Museum of the National Academy of Sciences
properties.description: Explore the current facts about climate change, including its potential causes and the possible future effects of global warming. Museum visitors will also learn about the personal, national and international actions that could reduce the negative effects of global warming.

properties.title: Jul 11, 2010: Wonders of Science at Marian Koshland Science Museum of the National Academy of Sciences
properties.description: Take a look at recent research that has been instrumental in unraveling some of the greatest mysteries of the universe.

properties.title: Jul 12, 2010: Black Box: Chris Chong Chan Fui at Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden
properties.description: Chris Chan Chong Fui, who lives and works in Kuala Lumpur, is the first Malaysian artist to present work at the Hirshhorn.

properties.title: Jul 12, 2010: Research Matters: Environmental and Toxicological Effects of Arsenic at National Museum of Health and Medicine
properties.description: This exhibit highlights the developing science of medical geology used by the museum's parent organization, the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology, to study health problems associated with exposure to toxic metals and metalloids such as arsenic.

properties.title: Jul 10, 2010: Grand Salon Installation - Paintings From the Smithsonian American Art Museum at Renwick Gallery
properties.description: This installation features 70 paintings from the Smithsonian American Art Museum's collection. On display will be landscapes, portraits, and allegorical works by 51 American artists from the 1840s to the 1930s. The room is installed salon style, with paintings hung one-atop-another and side by side. A visitor guide will be available in the Grand Salon with short biographies of the artists.

properties.title: Jul 11, 2010: Grand Salon Installation - Paintings From the Smithsonian American Art Museum at Renwick Gallery

The room is installed salon style, with paintings hung one-atop-another and side by side. A visitor guide will be available in the Grand Salon with short biographies of the artists.

The room is installed salon style, with paintings hung one-atop-another and side by side. A visitor guide will be available in the Grand Salon with short biographies of the artists.

properties.title: Jul 12, 2010: The Tibetan Shrine From the Alice S Kandell Collection at Arthur M Sackler Gallery
properties.description: On display for the first time is this extraordinary Tibetan Buddhist shrine room. Acknowledged by practicing Buddhists as a sacred space, this shrine room contains hundreds of superb works of Buddhist art created between the 12th and 19th centuries, including bronze sculptures, thangkas (scroll paintings), ritual objects, textile banners, and painted furniture, all presented in a religiously correct manner.

properties.title: Jul 12, 2010: Our Universes: Traditional Knowledge Shapes Our World at National Museum of Natural History
properties.description: Learn more about indigenous peoples from across the Western Hemisphere who continue to express the wisdom of their ancestors in celebration, language, art, spirituality and daily life.

properties.title: Jul 12, 2010: Our Peoples: Giving Voice to Our Histories at National Museum of Natural History
properties.description: Learn how Native people intentionally and strategically kept their cultures alive in the wake of the arrival of newcomers in the Western Hemisphere.

properties.title: Jul 11, 2010: Third Leg: Woodrow Wilson's Walking Sticks at Woodrow Wilson House Museum
properties.description: On display at the House Museum are over 30 of President Wilson's most prized walking sticks including elaborate examples of American folk art and historically significant presentation pieces. These important artifacts tell the story of Wilson's life from his early years as a professor and later president of Princeton University, through his two terms in the White House, to his final struggle with disability.

properties.title: Jul 11, 2010: Palace of Wonders: Renaissance and Baroque Galleries at The Walters Art Museum
properties.description: This display features a re-creation of a Collection of Art and Wonders as it might have been assembled by a 17th-century nobleman in the Southern Netherlands - his entry hall of arms and armor, a private study and a Chamber of Wonders encompassing curiosities of nature and human creativity.

properties.title: Jul 11, 2010: Guided Tours of Woodlawn Plantation at Woodlawn Plantation
properties.description: Woodlawn, a gracious 126-acre estate, was originally part of George Washington's Mount Vernon. In 1952, Woodlawn became the first historic site owned by The National Trust for Historic Preservation. Guided tours are provided every thirty minutes with the last tour at 4 pm.

properties.title: Jul 11, 2010: Baltimore Farmers' Market & Bazaar at Downtown Baltimore
properties.description: As Maryland's largest producers-only market, visitors can enjoy a one-of-a-kind shopping experience with economical prices. While strolling the market, shoppers can revel at the sight of the largest quantity of the freshest fruits and vegetables, organically raised and produced dairy products including a variety of cheeses, milk, yogurt and butter, and meats such as beef, pork, lamb, bison, chicken, turkey and capon; a complete selection of fresh fish, eggs, breads and pastries from Maryland area farmers, spices and salsas. In addition, food vendors add spice to the market with cultural cuisine, popular pit beef sandwiches, pastries, cheese, and gourmet treats. The bazaar offers shoppers a variety of unique crafts and collectibles great for gifts or home decor. Handmade items include jewelry, handbags, hair accessories, chairs, rugs, pottery and wooden crafts, stained glass, and artwork such as photographs. The Market is set up underneath the Jones Falls Expressway at Holliday and Saratoga streets

The exhibit includes Iooss's most famous photograph, 'The Catch,' which captured the last-minute touchdown catch by San Francisco 49ers' receiver Dwight Clark that ended the Dallas Cowboys' Super Bowl dreams in 1982. Also included are Iooss's personal diaries, filled with collages of his photos, quirky headlines and his handwritten notes. In addition, the exhibit includes an original Newseum-produced video in which Iooss talks about his photos and the bond he forged with his subjects.

properties.title: Jul 12, 2010: Postal Inspectors: the Silent Service at National Museum of American
properties.description: Today about 2,000 postal inspectors are at work across the United States investigating crimes against the mail. By visiting the museum and viewing this exhibit, you'll learn more about the inspectors and what their jobs entail. Sometimes called the silent service, the U.S. Postal Inspection Service is one of the oldest federal law enforcement agencies in the country.

properties.title: Jul 10, 2010: Supporting the Force: Navy Supply in Action - Ready for Sea, Ready Ashore at US Navy Memorial
properties.description: Navy Supply provides the "beans, bullets and black oil" that enable the US Navy to operate around the globe. Navy Supply touches the lives of every sailor with food, laundry, barbers, postal services and ship's stores. On display will be ship models, rare historic artifacts including an 1841 Navy Purser's uniform coat - the oldest known Navy Supply uniform - as well as a World War II WAVE uniform and the uniform and equipment worn by a Navy Advisor in the Vietnam War. In addition, the exhibit will honor the sailors of Navy Supply who've given their lives in the Global War on Terror and those who've received the Nation's top honors. Hands on activities for children include "build a meal" puzzles, interactive cargo handling display model and a "try-on trunk" with flight deck uniforms and equipment used during vertical replenishment operations. A full schedule of events will accompany the exhibit, including food tastings, films, lectures and equipment displays.

properties.title: Jul 10, 2010: Perspectives: Hai Bo at Arthur M Sackler Gallery
properties.description: Trained as a painter, Hai Bo, born in 1962 in Changchun, China, took up photography in the 1980s as he became captivated by the camera's ability to stop time and evoke memories. For over two decades, he has been returning to his hometown in Jilin Province to capture the people and places of his youth, creating deeply moving portraits of resilience amidst the growing isolation of rural China. On display are five stunning, large scale photographs from his Northern Series. These images allow viewers to enter the vast panoramas of the artist's childhood memories, observe the subtle changes of nature across seasons, and encounter the gentle transience of life.

properties.title: Jul 13, 2010: Evolution of the Microscope at National Museum of Health and Medicine
properties.description: This exhibit features items from the world's largest and most representative collection in tracing the development of the basic tool of the bioscientist over the last 400 years.

properties.title: Jul 13, 2010: To Bind Up the Nation's Wounds: Medicine During the Civil War at National Museum of Health and Medicine
properties.description: This exhibit shows Civil War medicine through the eyes of battlefield surgeons and the stories of Union and Confederate sick and wounded.

properties.title: Jul 13, 2010: Our Peoples: Giving Voice to Our Histories at National Museum of Natural History
properties.description: Learn how Native people intentionally and strategically kept their cultures alive in the wake of the arrival of newcomers in the Western Hemisphere.

properties.title: Jul 13, 2010: The Way We Genuinely Live - Masterworks of Yup'Ik Science and Survival at National Museum of Natural History
properties.description: In this exhibition, Yup'ik elders share their scientific and spiritual knowledge for living in the sub-arctic environment of western Alaska. On display are more than 200 19th- and 20th-century tools, clothing, weapons and watercraft.

properties.title: Jul 13, 2010: Third Leg: Woodrow Wilson's Walking Sticks at Woodrow Wilson House Museum
properties.description: On display at the House Museum are over 30 of President Wilson's most prized walking sticks including elaborate examples of American folk art and historically significant presentation pieces. These important artifacts tell the story of Wilson's life from his early years as a professor and later president of Princeton University, through his two terms in the White House, to his final struggle with disability.

properties.title: Jul 13, 2010: Gods of Angkor: Bronzes From the National Museum of Cambodia at Arthur M Sackler Gallery
properties.description: Revealed through 36 exceptional works on display in the Gallery, the fascinating story of bronze sculpture and casting in Cambodia is revealed. Magnificent examples dating from the prehistoric period to the post-Angkorian period (third century BCE to sixteenth century CE) present the origins, uses, and techniques of bronze casting and the development of a distinctly Cambodian style.

properties.title: Jul 13, 2010: Art by the Yard: Women Design Mid-Century Britain at Textile Museum
properties.description: Three women designers were pivotal in the artistic revolution in Britain after WWII: Lucienne Day (1917- 2010), Jacqueline Groag (1903-1985) and Marian Mahler (1911-1983). Incorporating dramatic saturated colors and bold motifs inspired by artists like Alexander Calder and Joan Miro, these young designers transformed the market by inspiring elegant yet affordable product lines that brought the world of contemporary art into everyone's homes. On display will be textiles together with preliminary drawings and collages, ceramics and period furniture, all drawn from the Jill A. Wiltse and H. Kirk Brown, III Collection of British Textiles.

properties.title: Jul 13, 2010: Deep Roots, Rising Waters at Banneker Douglass Museum
properties.description: This exhibition provides an overview of African American history in Maryland from 1633 through present day.

properties.title: Jul 13, 2010: Stabler-Leadbeater Apothecary Museum Permanent Collection at Stabler-Leadbeater Apothecary Museum
properties.description: When the Apothecary closed during the Depression, in 1933, the doors were simply locked, preserving the contents for history. The building reopened as a museum in 1939. Over 8,000 objects, including pill rollers, mortars and pestles, drug mills, and hand-blown medicine bottles with gold-leaf labels, were left in place. Medicinal herbs and paper labels remain in their wooden drawers. Large show-globes from the mid-19th century remain in the windows. The first floor room was fitted out in the Gothic Revival style around 1835, and still contains the apothecary furnishings of that period. On the second floor, wooden boxes, hand-lettered with numbers and names of herbs and medicines, line the walls and shelving. This supply room also contains tins, hand-blown bottles and paper labels for packaging the drugs. The Apothecary has a spectacular collection of archival materials, including journals, letter and diaries, prescription and formula books, ledgers and daybooks, orders and invoices, and stock certificates. A video program is available on the first floor for those unable to visit the second floor.

properties.title: Jul 13, 2010: Guided Winery Tours at Linganore Winecellars at Berrywine Plantation
properties.description: Learn the science and art of fine winemaking in a casual and fun atmosphere. Take a guided tour of the entire winemaking process, from the delicate crushing of vine-ripened fruits to the methodical bottling of the finished wines. There will be a complimentary wine sampling after the tour.

properties.title: Jul 13, 2010: Elvis - His Groundbreaking, Hip-Shaking, Newsmaking Story at Newseum
properties.description: Experience the power of Elvis Presley and the explosive impact he had on music and popular culture. The exhibit opens in what would have been Presley's 75th birthday year. It tells the story of Presley as he was portrayed in the news media and explores how his music and physicality pushed the boundaries of mainstream taste and free expression. Produced in collaboration with Elvis Presley Enterprises Inc., the exhibit includes a number of rare objects from the vaults of Graceland that have never been publicly displayed, including private telegrams, letters and documents that chronicle Presley's rise as a music and media sensation. Also on display are rare photographs and original newspapers and magazines covering Presley's career, Presley's iconic 1957 Harley-Davidson motorcycle, the "American Eagle" jumpsuit and cape Presley wore during rehearsals for his 1973 "Aloha From Hawaii" concert and the gold-and-diamond belt presented to Presley in 1969 for breaking Las Vegas attendance records.

properties.title: Jul 12, 2010: Apple-Soundtrack Pro : Sound 101 - Introduction to Sound Editing in Final Cut Studio at Future Media Concetps
properties.description: http://www.fmctraining.com/fmc.asp?l=Washington+DC&p2=Upcoming+Classesdc-reception@fmctraining.com Contact:202-429-9700 Fax:202-429-9898 (2 days) 07/12-07/13(Monday-Tuesday) 08/12-08/13(Thursday-Friday) 10/07-10/08(Thursday-Friday) 11/29-11/30(Monday-Tuesday) 12/20-12/21(Monday-Tuesday) Course Descriptions This two-day class guides you through editing audio files, repair field recordings, perform multitrack arranging and mixing, synchronize audio and video, analyze and fix common audio problems, and perform other creative sound design techniques. This course focuses on practical, professional techniques used to add professional music and sound effects to video and multimedia projects. Who should attend? This course is designed for those who want to learn the basics of audio content creation, editing, and mixing and who prefer hands-on, interactive instruction to best explore the audio functionality of Final Cut Studio. Prerequisites Students should have the following prerequisite knowledge prior to attending the course: • Basic knowledge of the Macintosh OS OS • Basic knowledge of audio terminology is recommended Course Outline - Day 1 Lesson 1: Sound Editing Basics • Understanding the Sound Editing Process, Cleaning Dialogue, Integrating Sound Effects and Adding Music Lesson 2: Sound Mixing Basics • Offline Mixing, Online Mixing, Mixing in Soundtrack Pro, Sending to a STP Multitrack Project, Performing Basic Mixing Tasks, Adjusting and Automating Levels, Conforming and Returning to Final Cut Pro Lesson 3: Getting to Know Soundtrack Pro • Using the Frequency Spectrum View, Controlling the Spectrum, and Working with Frequency Lesson 4: Recording in Soundtrack Pro • Understanding Panes, Tabs and Window Layouts, Setting Project Properties, Controlling Playback, Navigating the Timeline and Exploring the Track Header Lesson 5: Fixing Audio Files • Sending to an STP Audio File Project, Exploring the File Editor Project View, Navigating the Waveform Display, Redrawing Waveforms, Analyzing an Audio File, Working with Actions, Noise Reduction, Returning to Final Cut Pro and Saving an Action as an AppleScript Lesson 6: Recording Dialogue • Opening a Multitrack Project, Working with Tracks, Setting Up for Recording, Recording a Single Take, Collecting the Project and Using Punch Recording Course Outline - Day 2 Lesson 7: Editing Dialogue • Using the Editing Tools, Arranging Clips, Basic Mixing, Using the Noise Reduction Process and Adding with Ambient Noise Lesson 8: Multitake Editing (ADR) • Using the Multitake Editor, Adding a Guide Track, Organizing the Takes, Slipping Takes, Creating a Composite Take and Smoothing Transitions Lesson 9: Spotting Sound Effects • Setting Up for Spotting, Exploring the Bin and the Browser, Using the the Multipoint Video HUD, Three-Point Edits, Using Fades and Using Envelopes to Create Fades Lesson 10: Scoring Using Loops • Setting Up for Music Production, the Search Tab, Adding Music Beds, Working with Loops and Using Markers Lesson 11: Mixing Multitrack Projects Exploring the Mixer, Using Submixes, Adding DSP Effects to Mixer Tracks, Automating the Mix, Using Busses, Using the Master Channel and Surround Sound Mixing

Appearing like a gold-framed painting hanging on a wall, the artwork invites viewers to look inside to see reflections of themselves watching moving images repeatedly reflected in a spherical form.

properties.title: Jul 28, 2010: Grass Roots: African Origins of an American Art at Smithsonian National Museum of African Art
properties.description: By tracing the story of the beautiful coiled basket, 'Grass Roots' will revisit the history of the southeastern United States and will demonstrate the enduring contribution of African peoples and cultures to American life.

properties.title: Jul 28, 2010: A Rare Encounter: the Hope and Wittelsbach-Graff Diamonds at National Museum of Natural History
properties.description: You are invited to see the world's most extraordinary blue diamonds - the Hope and the Wittelsbach-Graff - displayed together for the first time. The Wittelsbach-Graff's deep blue color, flawless clarity, and royal history make it one of the most celebrated gemstones known. Both diamonds come from India and share their rare blue color. Could they have come from the same mine? Smithsonian scientists plan to compare the properties of both gems and explore this intriguing possibility.

properties.title: Jul 28, 2010: Gods of Angkor: Bronzes From the National Museum of Cambodia at Arthur M Sackler Gallery
properties.description: Revealed through 36 exceptional works on display in the Gallery, the fascinating story of bronze sculpture and casting in Cambodia is revealed. Magnificent examples dating from the prehistoric period to the post-Angkorian period (third century BCE to sixteenth century CE) present the origins, uses, and techniques of bronze casting and the development of a distinctly Cambodian style.

properties.title: Jul 28, 2010: First Dogs: Presidential Pets in the White House at Newseum
properties.description: One of the Newseum's most popular exhibits showcases some of the top dogs who have resided at the nation's most prestigious address. On display are images of dogs belonging to 23 presidents, including the newest addition: Bo, a six-month-old Portuguese water dog.

properties.title: Jul 28, 2010: Elvis - His Groundbreaking, Hip-Shaking, Newsmaking Story at Newseum
properties.description: Experience the power of Elvis Presley and the explosive impact he had on music and popular culture. The exhibit opens in what would have been Presley's 75th birthday year. It tells the story of Presley as he was portrayed in the news media and explores how his music and physicality pushed the boundaries of mainstream taste and free expression. Produced in collaboration with Elvis Presley Enterprises Inc., the exhibit includes a number of rare objects from the vaults of Graceland that have never been publicly displayed, including private telegrams, letters and documents that chronicle Presley's rise as a music and media sensation. Also on display are rare photographs and original newspapers and magazines covering Presley's career, Presley's iconic 1957 Harley-Davidson motorcycle, the "American Eagle" jumpsuit and cape Presley wore during rehearsals for his 1973 "Aloha From Hawaii" concert and the gold-and-diamond belt presented to Presley in 1969 for breaking Las Vegas attendance records.

properties.title: Jul 28, 2010: Supporting the Force: Navy Supply in Action - Ready for Sea, Ready Ashore at United States Navy Memorial and Naval Heritage Center
properties.description: Navy Supply provides the "beans, bullets and black oil" that enable the US Navy to operate around the globe. Navy Supply touches the lives of every sailor with food, laundry, barbers, postal services and ship's stores. On display will be ship models, rare historic artifacts including an 1841 Navy Purser's uniform coat - the oldest known Navy Supply uniform - as well as a World War II WAVE uniform and the uniform and equipment worn by a Navy Advisor in the Vietnam War. In addition, the exhibit will honor the sailors of Navy Supply who've given their lives in the Global War on Terror and those who've received the Nation's top honors. Hands on activities for children include "build a meal" puzzles, interactive cargo handling display model and a "try-on trunk" with flight deck uniforms and equipment used during vertical replenishment operations. A full schedule of events will accompany the exhibit, including food tastings, films, lectures and equipment displays.

properties.title: Jul 28, 2010: Athlete: the Sports Illustrated Photography of Walter Iooss at Newseum
properties.description: On display are more than 40 photos from Iooss's nearly 50-year career, each accompanied by the story behind the image, told in Iooss's own words. The exhibit includes Iooss's most famous photograph, 'The Catch,' which captured the last-minute touchdown catch by San Francisco 49ers' receiver Dwight Clark that ended the Dallas Cowboys' Super Bowl dreams in 1982. Also included are Iooss's personal diaries, filled with collages of his photos, quirky headlines and his handwritten notes. In addition, the exhibit includes an original Newseum-produced video in which Iooss talks about his photos and the bond he forged with his subjects.

properties.title: Jul 28, 2010: Postal Inspectors: the Silent Service at National Postal Museum
properties.description: Today about 2,000 postal inspectors are at work across the United States investigating crimes against the mail. By visiting the museum and viewing this exhibit, you'll learn more about the inspectors and what their jobs entail. Sometimes called the silent service, the U.S. Postal Inspection Service is one of the oldest federal law enforcement agencies in the country.

properties.title: Jul 28, 2010: Intersections Art Projects - Regi Muller at The Phillips Collection
properties.description: This spring Regi Muller transform the museum's Vradenburg Cafe by installing hundreds of peach-colored urethane Caps on its walls and windows. She is the winner of numerous awards and honors and has exhibited in her native Switzerland, as well as in the United States.

properties.title: Jul 28, 2010: Intersections Art Projects - Kate Shepherd: Relation to and Yet Not (Homage to Mondrian) at The Phillips Collection
properties.description: Kate Shepherd is best known for large, vertical, mostly monochrome paintings in hi-gloss enamel on wooden panels. Using intense colors, delicate lines, and multiple perspectives, she suggests structures and patterns - wallpaper, steps, lace, a cage, for example - that create illusionary three-dimensional space. Her work in the former dining room of the Phillips house incorporates painting and sculpture and focuses on architectural details.

properties.title: Jul 13, 2010: Intersections Art Projects - Kate Shepherd: Relation to and Yet Not (Homage to Mondrian) at The Phillips Collection
properties.description: Kate Shepherd is best known for large, vertical, mostly monochrome paintings in hi-gloss enamel on wooden panels. properties.title: Jul 13, 2010: Robert Ryman: Variations & Improvisations at The Phillips Collection
properties.description: Robert Ryman (b. 1930) is an American painter best known for abstract, white-on-white paintings. This exhibition presents Ryman's ongoing examination of painting as both medium and process with endless variations in materials and methods. It brings together approximately 25 small-scale paintings that are drawn from private collections, some of which have rarely been shown in the U.S. It is the first solo presentation of Ryman's work in the Washington area.

properties.title: Jul 28, 2010: Robert Ryman: Variations & Improvisations at The Phillips Collection

properties.title: Jul 13, 2010: American Modernism: the Shein Collection at National Gallery of Art - West Building
properties.description: On display are 20 important paintings, sculptures, and drawings by the first-generation American avant-garde. Among the artists represented in this exhibit are Patrick Henry Bruce, Stuart Davis, Charles Demuth, Arthur Dove, Marcel Duchamp, Marsden Hartley, Stanton Macdonald-Wright, John Marin, Georgia O'Keeffe, Man Ray, Morton Schamberg, Charles Sheeler, Joseph Stella, John Storrs and Max Weber. All works are from the Edward and Deborah Shein Collection, which is distinguished by its remarkable quality and rigorous focus on early American modernism.

properties.title: Jul 12, 2010: Luminous Warrior Mini-Healings in ChinaTown at Smithsonian American Art Museum
properties.description:
Do you need a BREAK from work?
Would you like a quick energy BOOST?
Would you like to EXPERIENCE Shamanic Healing?
If the answer is YES, then come on out to the Art Museum! Sara will be offering FREE Luminous Warrior mini-healings this summer to give you the boost YOU need to continue your day.
What can I expect?
When you arrive, Sara will welcome you and ask how you are feeling. You will have the option to remain seated on the blanket or lie down on your back to receive the healing. Sara will use Shamanic guidance to provide a combination of energy balancing, hands-on healing methods, Chakra cleansing techniques, essential oils and affirmations to facilitate the healing. If you are open to it, Sara may also provide messages that she receives from Spirit so that you can reconnect with your own authentic self. You will return to work balanced, peaceful, alert and refreshed.
When and Where?
Luminous Warrior Mini-Healings will take place EVERY MONDAY from 12pm-2pm, beginning June 21 and ending July 19. Find Sara at the American Art Museum in Chinatown. She will be sitting on a blanket at the indoor glass- ceiling courtyard, across the café.
What does it cost?
It’s FREE! If you feel the urge to provide something in reciprocity, feel free to bring a donation or small gift (flower, stone...). There is NO need to register.
Why is this being offered?
Sara would like to introduce you to Luminous Warrior. She also believes in the principle of Ayni, a Quechua word meaning reciprocity. This is her way of giving to her community. Simply come out and allow yourself to receive!

properties.title: Jul  9, 2010: Nage Bistro Offers Special Red Fish Sandwich Fundraiser to Benefit Gulf Coast Relief Efforts at Nage Bistro
properties.description:
From now until January 2011, Gulf Coast native and executive chef at Nage Bistro, Glenn Babcock will offer a special red fish sandwich for $10, with all profits benefitting Gulf Coast relief, specifically to support fishermen, shrimpers and oystermen whose livelihoods are threatened by the oil spill.
The Gulf Coast Red Fish Sandwich is prepared in traditional Gulf Coast fashion and features a filet of buttery, mild red fish which is blackened and topped with lemon caper aioli. It is served on a house made ciabatta roll with lettuce and tomato and comes with a side of green cabbage slaw.

properties.title: Jul  9, 2010: CycleLife Free Rides During Georgetown Healthy Days of Summer at CycleLife
properties.description:
CycleLife hosts a free 'beginner's ride' every Friday at noon and a free 'DC Velo' fast group bike ride every Saturday from 7 to 9 a.m. They also host a power lunch boot camp every Monday and Wednesday where the first class is free.
Georgetown Healthy Days of Summer
Throughout the month of July, Georgetown, D.C. will host "Healthy Days of Summer 2010," a healthy living promotion showcasing the neighborhood's variety of outdoor activities, numerous fitness-minded merchants and healthy dining options. Georgetown will play host to several creative health initiatives throughout the month ranging from outdoor yoga classes to free group bike rides to encourage a life of wellness and make healthy living fun, easy, and accessible.
Georgetown's "Healthy Days of Summer" month aims to promote healthy living by providing residents with exciting hosted physical activities, and healthy menu options at area restaurants, while highlighting the neighborhood's various places to keep active on a regular basis.

properties.title: Jul 10, 2010: Free Yoga Series at Baltimore's Inner Harbor at West Shore Park ((between the Visitor's Center and Maryland Science Center) on the Inner Harbor Promenade
properties.description: Charm City Yoga and the Waterfront Partnership of Baltimore will offer FREE Seva Yoga classes at West Shore Park on the Inner Harbor Promenade this summer.  Classes begin Saturday, June 26, from 9 - 10am, and will be led by Charm City Yoga’s Sarah Cook.  Seva Yoga is a donation-based yoga class where people can participate free of charge but are encouraged to make a donation – either monetary or time-based - to the cause or charity of their choice. In addition, participants should feel free to set the intention for their yoga practice to benefit the cause as well.  Bring your friends, introduce them to Seva Yoga, and help grow your cause.  The yoga classes at West Shore Park are designed to be suitable for all levels of students.

properties.title: Jul 28, 2010: Free Lunchtime Art Workshops at National Museum of Health and Medicine
properties.description:
Enjoy a short discussion about artworks featured in “Wounded in Action: An Art Exhibition of Orthopaedic Advancements” and then spend time creating your own work of art. Explore different media each week in the workshops featured below.
*Wednesday, July 21: Sketch wounds as seen in wax models from the Museum’s Historical Collections.
*Wednesday, July 28: Draw medical technology, including historic prosthetic devices.
*Wednesday, August 4: Sketch sculptures that depict the human form. 
These workshops  will be be held 12 p.m. to 1 p.m. and are free, but reservations are required. Ages 15 & up. To reserve a spot or for more information, call 202-782-2673. Art supplies will be provided, but attendees are welcome to bring their favorite materials.
NMHM  is located in Building 54 on the campus of the Walter Reed Army Medical Center. Limited visitor parking is available in the driveway in front of the museum. Additional free parking is available throughout the campus on weekends. Adults are required to present photo ID to gain entry to Walter Reed.

properties.title: Sep  1, 2010: Acoustic Soul at Indulj
properties.description:
Every Wednesday and Friday, from 7-10PM, slow things down for a unique fine dining experience in the heart of the city. While enjoying the soothing sounds of CoolFire's acoustic R&B music, sample Indulj's many delectable tapas and savory entrees in a quaint and classy atmosphere, minus the loud music and rowdy crowd found in many area bars and lounges. After a hard day at work, CoolFire’s mellow vibe provides the perfect back...drop for a relaxing and pleasing dinner. Check out this week’s featured items:
Santos Wings - grilled then baked with a zesty seasoning blend
Jerk Wings - grilled then baked in an authentic Jamaican jerk sauce
Down Home Spring Rolls - fusion at it’s best! Indulj’s signature collard greends, yellow rice deep-fried in a crispy wonton wrapper
Skewer Trio - salmon, beef & chicken skewers served over yellow rice
Lousiana Catfish Nuggets - crispy fried catfish nuggets served with homemade Remoulade Sauce
Seafood Lingiuni - clams, calamari, shrimp and scallops in a spicy tomato sauce
Grilled Salmon - with roasted potatoes and sautéed spinach
Arborio Rice - with shrimp and shitake mushrooms
____________________________________________________
Admission: FREE
Crowd: 30+ and up
Dress: Casual/Business casual
Atmosphere: Relaxing, candlelit tables, conversation-friendly
Music: CoolFire's acoustic R&B set features 2 guitar players, and covers the music of Marvin Gaye, Donny Hathaway, Stevie Wonder, Luther Vandross, Maxwell, Sade, Jill Scott, Erykah Badu, Ledisi, and many more!
Perfect for: “Date Night”, Married Couples, Girls Night Out, First Dates, Casual Business meetings, Pre-nightclub dinner, Birthday Dinners and celebrations, post-workout meal - shower required :), and “I don’t feel like cooking” Nights!
Indulj Lounge
1208 U Street, NW
Washington DC 20009
(across from Ben's Chili Bowl)
To reserve a table visit www.opentable.com or call 202-986-9400 and mention CoolFire. For more info on CoolFire visit www.coolfiresoul.com

properties.title: Sep  2, 2010: Adobe-Advanced ColdFusion 9 Development at Future Media Concepts
properties.description: http://www.fmctraining.com/fmc.asp?l=Washington+DC&p2=Upcoming+Classesdc_reception@yahoo.com Contact:202-429-9700 / MartinD@FMCtraining.com (3 day class) 9/2-4(Thur-Sat), 12/2-4(Thur-Sat) Description Advanced ColdFusion 9 Development provides ColdFusion application developers with the knowledge and hands-on practice that they need to build, maintain, and scale effective web applications. Topics include using the Application Framework, creating advanced queries, manipulating complex data in arrays and structures, structuring your code with ColdFusion Components, gracefully handling errors and exceptions, encapsulating your user-interface with custom tags, leveraging external Java code libraries, and creating highly interactive interfaces using Flash Forms. It includes optional content on exposing and reusing application functionality as web services and working with XML documents. This course focuses on creating and delivering scalable and well-performing applications. Audience This course is for developers with prior ColdFusion experience. To take this course, you should have: • Complete the Fast Track to ColdFusion 9 course, or the equivalent experience building ColdFusion applications. • Experience developing web applications using ColdFusion for at least three months upon completion of the Fast Track to ColdFusion 9 course. • Practical experience using CFML tags, functions and variables. • Practical experience with the SQL command set, including SELECT, INSERT and UPDATE COURSE OUTLINE Lesson 1: Introduction to Components * Creating ColdFusion Components * Introducing CFC Syntax * Invoking Static CFC Methods * Using the Application Framework * Configuring Application Settings * Handling Application Events * Handling Request Events * Locking Shared Scope Variables * Handling Session Events Lesson 2: Manipulating Lists Sep  2, 2010: Abbey Road on the River at Gaylord National Hotel & Convention Center
properties.description: The world's largest Beatles tribute festival, Abbey Road on the River, will bring five days of peace to National Harbor, MD. The Labor Day Weekend music festival will draw thousands of Beatles fans to the stunning Gaylord National Resort, which will be home base for festival bands and attendees, hosting five indoor and outdoor stages, seminars, and a Beatles merchandise market place. Festival highlights include a special presentation from original Beatles drummer Pete Best on his never-before-heard experiences with the band, a presentation from Gretsch owner Fred Gretsch, III, illustrations from famed animator Ron Campbell, on-site podcasts of the Fab Fourum talk show, and a huge selection of Beatles art and collectibles. In addition, on Saturday, September 4th Hal Bruce and his new band, Hard Dazed Knights, will perform 214 Beatles songs as one continuous medley with no breaks or intermission. The 30 performing Beatles tribute bands, from Mop Tops to Sgt. Peppers, represent countries from around the world including Italy, England, Germany, Scotland, Canada, and the United States. Fans will hear the entire discography of The Beatles from 1963's 'Please Please Me' through John, Paul, George and Ringo's final album together 'Abbey Road' (1970). For guests who love the music they made as solo artists, the event will feature special concerts dedicated to their careers after they became famous. It all "comes together" on the banks of the Potomac River, giving the attendees the ultimate Fab Four Weekend. Tickets purchased in advance include free admission for one 21 and under guest with each regular ticket holder.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: John Witherspoon from "The Boondocks," "House Party" and the "Friday" trilogy at DC Improv Comedy Club
properties.description:
You probably remember John Witherspoon as Ice Cube's outrageously funny, dog-catching father in the "Friday" movie trilogy, where the two were the only cast members to appear in all three movies, including "Next Friday" & "Friday After Next." You may also remember him as Pops on the long-running sitcom "The Wayans Brothers," or as Spoon on The Tracy Morgan Show on NBC. You might have also heard him as the voice of Robert "Granddad" Freeman on the hit animated series "The Boondocks." No matter how familiar you are with John, once you see him perform live you completely understand why he's has earned his reputation as one of the funniest dads in America.
John's scene-stealing roles in "Boomerang," "Little Nicky," "House Party," "Vampire in Brooklyn," and "I'm Gonna Git You Sucka," has established him as a Hollywood mainstay. Witherspoon's resume spans over four decades and his performances in blockbuster movies, hit-television shows, and top-rated music videos have left an impression on legions of fans who instantly recognize his signature catchphrases like "Bang!Bang!Bang!Bang!" "You gotta co-ordinate!" and "Don't nobody go in the bathroom..."
According to the Orange County Register, John's expressive talent puts him in a class of his own. "Witherspoon is one of those performers who doesn't need a funny line to be funny. Just standing there in a truculent posture with a suspicious look, he is funny and enlivens every scene he's in." The Detroit-bred comic has proven that he is a Hollywood mainstay and continues to land coveted spots in some of America's favorite movies and television shows. Witherspoon continues to tour around the country with his wildly popular stand-up show, plus he's recently launched The John Witherspoon Collection, a complete line of humorous greeting cards called Spoon Cards.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: 150th Commemoration of the Civil War: the Death of Ellsworth at National Portrait Gallery
properties.description: This exhibition recounts the death of Colonel Elmer E. Ellsworth in Alexandria, VA. Ellsworth, a friend of President Abraham Lincoln, was the first Union officer to be killed in the four-year-long struggle. Throughout the Civil War his name, face and heroism was recalled in stationery, sheet music and memorial lithographs. Francis E. Brownell, the soldier who mortally avenged Ellsworth's assailant, bequeathed several artifacts to the Smithsonian Institution, including the weapons used in the incident and Brownell's Congressional Medal of Honor. The exhibition will bring together a select grouping of once-prized mementoes, including portraits of Ellsworth and Lincoln, as well as Alonzo Chappel's historic painting, 'The Death of Ellsworth.'

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Capital Portraits: Treasures From Washington Private Collections at National Portrait Gallery
properties.description: This exhibition presents portraits that reside in private Washington, D.C. collections. Many of the works have never been on public display. Works included are by major artists such as John Singleton Copley, Mary Cassatt, Andy Warhol and Kehinde Wiley. Featuring aesthetically superior images from 1750 to the present, this exhibition demonstrates how portraiture is ingrained in the private sphere of people's lives and offers an insiders peek to the public.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: To Make A World: George Ault and 1940s America at Smithsonian American Art Museum
properties.description: This exhibition centers on five paintings Ault made between 1943 and 1948 depicting the crossroads of Russell's Corners in Woodstock, N.Y. The additional 22 artists represented in this exhibition include some as celebrated as Edward Hopper and Andrew Wyeth, while others are scarcely known to today's art audiences. Taken together, their artworks reveal an aesthetic vein running through 1940s American art that previously has not been identified. From their remote corners of the country, these artists conveyed a still quietude that seems filled with potentialities.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Close to Home: Photographers and Their Families at Smithsonian American Art Museum
properties.description: 'Close to Home' presents photographs made during the past three decades by both established and emerging artists. On display are 32 color and black-and-white photographs from the Smithsonian American Art Museum's permanent collection by nine contemporary photographers: Tina Barney, Virginia Beahan, Christopher Dawson, Muriel Hasbun, Martina Lopez, Elaine O'Neil, Larry Sultan, Margaret Strickland, and Carrie Will. The exhibition includes many new acquisitions, which will be on view at the museum for the first time. Toby Jurovics, formerly the museum's curator of photography, selected the photographs in the installation.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Calder's Portraits: A New Language at National Portrait Gallery
properties.description: Best known for his abstract mobiles and stabiles, Alexander Calder (1898-1976) was also a prolific portraitist. This unprecedented exhibition will feature Calder's work alongside contemporary documents - photographs, drawings, and especially caricatures by such artist-illustrators as Paolo Garretto, Miguel Covarrubias, and Paul Colin - and will pose questions regarding the line between fine-art portraiture and caricature.

properties.title: Jul  7, 2011: Glimpse of the Past: A Neighborhood Evolves at National Portrait Gallery
properties.description: 'Glimpse of the Past' is a photographic exploration of the neighborhood surrounding the Patent Office Building, one of the oldest federal buildings in Washington, D.C. and now home to the Smithsonian's National Portrait Gallery and the Smithsonian American Art Museum. On display are images from the 1850s to the present, which showcase the rise, decline and revival of the area. An interactive in the exhibition will also feature snapshots of the area during the 1960s and 1970s made by Washingtonian Chris Earnshaw.
